awd_titl_txt: Meeting: Predator-Prey Interactions Evolution of Form and Function (GRC January 29-February 4th, 2022 in Lucca Italy)
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will broaden participation at the 2022 Gordon Research Conference (GRC) on Predator-Prey Interactions by directly supporting the attendance of members of historically excluded groups, those serving in undergraduate or minority-serving institutions, and early career researchers. At the conference, attendees will participate in numerous formal and informal mentoring events, including a two-day Gordon Research Seminar (GRS) open to graduate students and postdoctoral researchers. These events are designed to enhance the exposure of supported attendees’ research and promote interaction and collaboration with more senior established researchers. In addition to requiring all attendees to present research at the GRS, there are 8 presentation opportunities at the main GRC that have been set aside for attendees that are supported by this award. Lastly, attendees will be invited to lead manuscripts in a Special Issue publication with topics derived from the conference discussion groups, formalizing the process through which collaborations can continue post-conference. As such, this award enhances the scientific and professional development of a more diverse group of early-career researchers who would otherwise most likely not be able to attend. 

The Gordon Research Conference on Predator-Prey Interactions has occurred bi-annually since 2014 and the insights and novel research papers produced from these conferences have advanced the field of predator-prey interactions. Given the pervasive and critical importance of predation across animal species and ecosystems, the goal of this conference is to foster cross-pollination of ideas among disciplines from evolution and ecology to wildlife management to neurobiology and biomedicine. This interdisciplinary meeting has resulted in a variety of novel approaches, perspectives, and publications. The 2022 meeting will focus on understanding the relationship between phenotype and fitness from a functionally integrative, evolutionary perspective. As such, it will entail path-breaking advances in our understanding of animal forms, designs, and strategies that represent optimal solutions in a variety of environments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This funding was aimed at supporting the participation of underrepresented minorities (URMs) and early career researchers (ECRs) at the Predator-Prey Interactions Gordon Research Conference. Specifically, we had two major goals for this funding. The first, to broaden participation, access, and inclusion through focused and targeted marketing, the promotion of an inclusive environment, and financial support of underserved or under-resourced individuals. The second, to provide professional development and mentorship opportunities to ECRs through new programs aimed at enhancing the value of the conference, increasing the exposure of their research, and providing formalized mentorship.

We aimed to support 19 early career researchers and underrepresented minorities. We were able to support 20 early career researchers and URMs. This funding supported 13 graduate students, 3 post-docs, and 4 early career assistant professors (2 of which were post-docs at the time of funding allocation). 15 women, 4 men, and 1 non-binary person were supported. All 20 presented either a poster or a presentation at both the Gordon Research Seminar or the Gordon Research Conference

At the conference, there were 3 focused opportunities for professional development of supported participants. The first, was a mentor/mentee meeting where we paired ECRs with a later career scientist. They met for at least 1 hour to discuss a range of topics, including career advice and research project advice. The second, was a dinner seating event. At all GRCs, all participants eat their meals together. We organized a seating plan that alternated ECRs with later career researchers such that at any table there would be half ECRs and half LCRs. Both of these events were held early in the conference so that informal meetings, meals, and general conversations could continue between the mentee and their mentor. Generally, the feedback from these two events was extremely positive, from both ECRs and LCRs, and we will be implementing them into all future GRCs.

In addition to the two above events, we also held a formal break out 'Power Hour' with a focus on imposter syndrome. This was attended by approximately 50 attendees (including those supported by this funding), most of whom were ECRs. This event was extremely valuable to all those that attended. It allowed them to recognize and confront their own imposter syndrome but also, and importantly, it provided them a community and understanding that their feelings were not unusual and that many in our field suffer from the same. During this event we also discussed ways in which we may be able to overcome such feelings.

Modified by: Michael J Sheriff
